title: How to Maintain Bermuda Grass

steps.headline: Use a reel mower to get a close cut.
steps.description: Purchase a reel mower from a local home improvement store. These mowers cut the blades of grass vertically in a scissor-like movement as opposed to a regular rotary mower that cuts horizontally. Reel mowers allow the blade to be set closer to the ground than traditional mowers, which prevent the mower from scalping the grass. While reel mowers are a more expensive option than a traditional mower, a reel mower will allow you to get a closer cut.

steps.headline: Set the blade to the appropriate height.
steps.description: Early in the grass growing season (April-May), set the blade height to 1 inch (2.5 cm). During summer months (June-August) raise the blade to 1.5 in (3.8 cm). After the growing season is over (September-October), set the blade to 2 in (5.1 cm). During the fall (October-November), when the grass is dormant, you only need to mow on rare occasions. To prevent putting stress on the grass, do not take off more than one-third of the total height.

steps.headline: Leave lawn clippings behind to help fertilize the grass.
steps.description: If you want a cheap and easy way to nourish your lawn, leaving the lawn clippings after you’re finished allows nitrogen to return to the soil. If you prefer a cleaner look, feel free to pick up the clippings. However, you will not get the benefits of the free fertilizer that comes from the clippings.

steps.headline: Water the grass when the blades begin to droop.
steps.description: Look to see if the tops of the blades are bending down toward the ground or are a bluish color. If either of these occur, or if you see visible brown spots, the grass should be watered.

steps.headline: Water the grass for 30 minutes per session.
steps.description: Test the level of watering by pushing a screwdriver into the soil. If it sinks down easily 6 in (15 cm) into the ground, do not continue to water. If it is difficult to push the screwdriver to this depth, water the grass for 10 more minutes and test again. The length of time you water the grass during each season will depend on the weather, temperature, and your test for how much watering it takes to stick the screwdriver in 6 in (15 cm).

steps.headline: Adjust how often you water the grass based on the season.
steps.description: During spring months, the grass can be watered every 10 days. During hot summer months, when the grass is doing most of its growing, water every 5 - 10 days. During fall months, water every 10 days.

steps.headline: Use a hose or irrigation system to water the grass.
steps.description: Put a nozzle on the end of a hose with different settings to allow more less water out of the hose. You can also irrigate the lawn with timed sprinklers to save time. These systems allow water to run under the ground to sprinkler heads at various spots on your lawn. Set up your irrigation system to water the grass on a regular schedule every 5 to 10 days. If the temperature and weather are drier and hotter than normal, water every 6 to 7 days. If it is cooler and rain showers occur, water every 10 or more days.

steps.headline: Check for run-off to make sure you are not watering for too long.
steps.description: Watch the lawn, gutters, and sidewalks as you water. When water starts to run into the gutters and street, note the time it took to do so. That is the maximum amount of time you should water at once. Try turning or adjusting your sprinkler heads to face away from driveways and sidewalks.

steps.headline: Aerate the grass in early summer when it is growing quickly.
steps.description: Depending on your location's weather and temperature, this may be between April to June. If you have an underground irrigation system, make sure to place a flag or other marker where the sprinkler heads are so you don't damage them.

steps.headline: Use an aerator that has hollow tines or spoons.
steps.description: These endings allow the aerator to cut out out small pieces of soil to allow the dirt to breath. Push the aerator from one side of the lawn to the other. Then, turn around and push it back to the other side of the lawn, covering the next line of grass. When you have covered the lawn, turn the aerator perpendicular to the lines you just made and repeat going up and down the lawn. Look at 1 ft (30 cm) of lawn. There should be at least 12 holes in the area. If there are less, go over the lawn again with the aerator.

steps.headline: Apply fertilizer and water after aerating to help the grass recover quickly.
steps.description: Use the same amount of fertilizer you normally do based on your calculations and type of fertilizer you chose. Water the lawn as you normally would to fully cover the grass and to reach a depth of 6 in (15 cm).

steps.headline: Fertilize the grass annually when it starts turning green.
steps.description: Depending on your region, the weather, and temperature, this time may differ. However, it is usually during the springs months between April and June. Also, make sure there is no chance of a late frost that could kill the newly sprouted grass blades. If you fertilize too early, the cool temperature and frost will not allow the fertilizer to be properly absorbed by the grass.

steps.headline: Choose a fertilizer that has a 3-1-2 ratio of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium.
steps.description: Look on the outside of the bag for 3 numbers listed. The numbers represent the percent of each nutrient in the bag. For example, a 20 - 4 - 8 means there is 20% nitrogen, 4% phosphorus, and 8% nitrogen.

steps.headline: Measure the right amount of fertilizer by following the bag's directions.
steps.description: Follow the rule that you need at least 1 lb (0.45 kg) of nitrogen for every growing month per 1,000 ft (300 m). Calculate the amount of complete fertilizer you need to use based on the percent of nitrogen in the bag and the bag’s total weight. For example, if the bag weights 25 lb (11 kg) and has 20% nitrogen, you would multiply 25 lb (11 kg) X 0.2 to find the total weight of nitrogen in the bag. In this case, there are 5 lb (2.3 kg) of nitrogen in the bag.

steps.headline: Use a drop spreader to have more control over the fertilizer placement.
steps.description: These spreaders have holes on the bottom of the bucket where the fertilizer drops out as you push it over the lawn. Look at the fertilizer bag for instructions on what setting to adjust the drop spreader to so the right amount of fertilizer is being dropped as you roll the spreader across the lawn.

steps.headline: Use a cyclone spreader to cover more area at one time.
steps.description: This spreader has a rotating disk below the bucket that sprays the fertilizer in multiple direction as it drops out of the bucket. Make sure the spreader is calibrated according to the instructions on the fertilizer bag. Turn the calibrating knob on the spreader to adjust the number.

steps.headline: Water the grass for 30 minutes after fertilizing.
steps.description: Test to make sure the grass got enough water by pushing a screwdriver into the lawn. If it easily sinks down 6 in (15 cm), the grass has enough water. Use a hose and nozzle to manually water the entire area of the lawn. You can also use a sprinkler if you don’t want to water the lawn yourself.
